p: Provides a consistent, machine-readable way of accessing date values. Facilitates delivery, especially as regards the ability to perform full-text searches for specific dates or date ranges.

list.label: numbered sequentially throughout
list.item: If the notes are numbered sequentially throughout the entire work, use the printed note number, prefixed with n (short for note). For example, n1, n2, n3, etc.
list.label: numbered within each chapter
list.item: If the note numbering starts over at 1 in each chapter, create a unique ID by including the chapter number as well as the note number. For example, the note IDs for the third chapter would be n3.1, n3.2, n3.3, etc.
list.label: identified on each page
list.item: If the note numbers or symbols start over on each page, create a unique ID by numbering the notes sequentially within each chapter. For example, if the 35th footnote in chapter VI is indicated by an asterisk (*), the id would be n6.35 and the note body would be marked: <note id="n6.35" place="foot"><ns>*</ns>...</note> <note id="n6.35" place="foot"><seg type="note-symbol">*</seg>...</note>

summary.p: The XML source for this documentation describes the local markup practices for TEI-encoded electronic texts followed by Digital Library Production Services (DLPS), University of Virginia Library. It contains three types of markup practices:

list.item: those applicable only to keyboarding/encoding vendors (vendor practices)
those applicable only after a text has been received from a vendor (postkb practices)
those applicable to both (global practices)

summary.p: The documentation is intended to be helpful in three main ways:

list.item: as a set of encoding guidelines for keyboarding/encoding vendors who produce TEI texts for DLPS
as a reference for DLPS staff when working on QA/correction, markup enhancement, migration, etc. of TEI texts
as a reference for authors of delivery systems for the digital library, when creating delivery mechanisms for TEI texts produced by DLPS

argument.p: This document describes the text encoding practices for initial document production (keyboarding) followed by Digital Library Production Services (DLPS), University of Virginia Library. It is intended for use by keyboarding vendors when encoding electronic texts for DLPS.

admon.p: When referring to elements div1 through div7 as a group, the pseudo-tag divN is used for example, The type attribute is required on divN elements.

argument.p: This document describes the local markup practices for TEI-encoded electronic texts followed by Digital Library Production Services (DLPS), University of Virginia Library. It is intended to be helpful in two main ways:

list.item: as a reference for DLPS staff when working on QA/correction, markup enhancement, migration, etc. of TEI texts
as a reference for authors of delivery systems for the digital library, when creating delivery mechanisms for TEI texts produced by DLPS

admon.p: When referring to elements div1 through div7 as a group, the pseudo-tag divN is used for example, The type attribute is required on divN elements.

practice.head: XML form of TEI
practice.desc: All TEI documents produced for DLPS must be encoded in the XML expression of TEI (not SGML).

practice.head: The transcription
practice.desc: The electronic text should contain an exact character-for-character transcription of the text of the print source.

practice.head: Including all content
practice.desc: With very few exceptions, all printed content from the print source must be included in the electronic text. All textual data must be included in the transcription, and all non-textual (graphical) data must be included in the markup as figure elements.

exceptions.p: The only exceptions to this rule are:

list.label: Running page headers

item.p: Exclude the running headers that often appear at the top of each page in a printed book. (These headers are typically very repetitive and only contain content already available elsewhere in the electronic transcription, such as the title of the book or the title of the current chapter.)

admon.p: In rare cases, running page headers will contain unique content (such as a summary of the content of the current page). In such cases DLPS will require that the running headers be included in the electronic text. See .

list.label: Handwriting
list.item: When transcribing printed materials, handwriting (such as readers notes or markings) should be excluded from the transcription.
list.label: Gaps
list.item: Gaps in the transcription are necessary in some cases, typically either because a passage is missing from the print source (due to a missing or torn page, for example), or because the print source contains non-Western characters. Any and all omissions in the electronic transcription must be indicated by the gap/ element. See .

practice.head: XML declaration
practice.desc: All XML documents produced for DLPS should begin with an XML declaration, which should include version with value 1.0. The encoding declaration should either be omitted or set to UTF-8.

remarks.p: Omitting the encoding declaration is equivalent to specifying UTF-8, because UTF-8 is the assumed/default encoding for all XML documents.

exemplum.eg: <?xml version="1.0"?>

remarks.p: Compliance with this practice is automated: The processing script replace_xml_decl programmatically replaces the vendors XML declaration with our own.

reason.p: While not strictly required by XML, including the XML declaration is good practice.

practice.head: ASCII encoding
practice.desc: The entire XML file (transcription and markup) must not contain any illegal control characters nor any super-ASCII characters. That is, all characters in the file must have ASCII/Unicode code points of 9 (tab), 10 (newline/linefeed), 13 (carriage return), or 32-126 (space - tilde).

remarks.p: All super-ASCII characters must be represented as character entities.

Compliance with this practice is automated: The processing script char2ent programmatically replaces super-ASCII characters with character entities (named/mnemonic entities when available, hex numeric entities otherwise).

reason.p: Portability

practice.head: Line endings
practice.desc: If the XML files contain PC, two-byte line endings (carriage return + linefeed), convert them to Unix, one-byte line endings (linefeed character) before calculating character output and delivering the finished files to DLPS.

practice.head: Filenaming convention
practice.desc: Each XML file produced for DLPS should be named with its DLPS ID, which is a lower-case b or z followed by 9 digits, and with the extension .xml. The DLPS ID is in the teiHeader supplied to the vendor by DLPS (see idno type="DLPS ID").

practice.head: External notes document
practice.desc: For each file prepared for DLPS, include a separate notes document, external to the TEI XML file and in plain-text form. This notes document should include information on any unusual circumstances encountered in the transcription or encoding process, such as oddities or errors in the print source, or how ambiguous or problematic parts of the text have been handled. The notes file should be named with the DLPS ID followed by _notes.txt.

exemplum.eg: b000090177_notes.txt z000000032_notes.txt

practice.head: Basic document structure
practice.desc: Follow the essential structural markup common to most TEI texts: TEI.2 contains teiHeader and text; the text element contains front, body, and back. (The back element is optional; technically, front is also optional, though it is extremely rare to have a text with no front matter whatsoever.)

exemplum.eg: <TEI.2> <teiHeader> . . . [supplied by DLPS to the keyboarding vendor] </teiHeader> <text> <front> . . . [front matter: title page, table of contents, preface, etc.] </front> <body> . . . [main body of text] </body> <back> . . . [back matter: endnotes, index, appendices, etc.] </back> </text> </TEI.2>

remarks.p: Of course, the DTD cannot ensure appropriate use of front, body, and back.

practice.head: TEI header
practice.desc: The teiHeader element will be supplied by DLPS to the vendor.

practice.head: Composite texts
practice.desc: In rare cases, DLPS will request that a particular text be marked as a composite text, in which the usual body element is replaced with the group element, which then contains multiple text elements, each with its own front, body, and back.

remarks.p: DLPS will only request a composite text in the case of anthologies or collected works, where each work has its own front and/or back matter.

exemplum.eg: <TEI.2> <teiHeader> . . . [metadata section supplied by DLPS to the keyboarding vendor] </teiHeader> <text> <front> . . . [front matter for the collection] </front> <group> <text> <front> . . . [front matter of first text] </front> <body> . . . [main body of first text] </body> <back> . . . [back matter of first text] </back> </text> <text> <front> . . . [front matter of second text] </front> <body> . . . [main body of second text] </body> <back> . . . [back matter of second text] </back> </text> </group> <back> . . . [back matter for the collection] </back> </text> </TEI.2>

remarks.p: qa_lib_structure issues a warning if the group element is used, so that the QA tech can check the markup manually. No DTD or program can ensure proper use of group.

practice.head: Top-level divisions
practice.desc: Top-level structural divisions are always div1; div and div0 are not used.

practice.head: All content within a div
practice.desc: The front, body, and back elements must contain only div1 elements. No content is allowed directly within front, body, or back.

practice.head: Typed divs
practice.desc: The type attribute is required on divN elements, and it has an enumerated vocabulary of allowed values. If a division has no obvious type, the generic value section may be used; if section has already been used for a higher-level division, use subsection.

remarks.p: Most of the available type values are self-explanatory, and no definition is provided for them here. Those that are not necessarily self-explanatory are:

list.item: for brief biographic sketches of authors or other contributors
for a list of characters preceding a dramatic work
for biographical or historical timelines
a section at or near the end of a book, containing printing information such as name of printer (as distinct from publisher), typefaces used, etc.
for tables of contents and for lists of illustrations, etc.
for opinion pieces in newspapers
for journal entries or encyclopedia/dictionary entries
for lists of printing errors; also called corrigenda
like a half-title page, but occurs between the front matter and the body; treat as last page of front matter (not first page of body); see

technically, an illustration facing the title page; may also be used for any full-page illustration in the front matter, or for an illustration facing the first page of a major division within the body
a page preceding the title page bearing the title of the work, perhaps with a series title or volume number; see
a block of matter in a newspaper or other periodical indicating title of publication, address, list of editors or other contributors, etc.
one or more full-page illustrations, often unnumbered or numbered independently of main pagination
for a transcript of an oration, not for a piece of dialog in a dramatic work (for which use sp)

remarks.p: Although the DTD requires type on divs and enumerates the allowable values, obviously the DTD cannot enforce appropriate use of the available type values.

practice.head: n on divs
practice.desc: If a division is numbered or otherwise labeled in the print source (this should be obvious from the divisions heading), record the number or label in the n attribute (in addition to transcribing it as part of the head). If the division does not have a number or other label associated with it, do not include the n attribute.

remarks.p: The value of n does not have to be strictly numeric; often it will be a roman numeral or letter.

exemplum.eg:
INTRODUCTION I 1—IMPORTANCE OF THE PO HU T'UNG.

The Po hu t'ung pretends to be the official report of the discussions | on the Classics which were held under Imperial auspices in 79 A.D., |

INTRODUCTION I 1—IMPORTANCE OF THE PO HU T'UNG.

The Po hu t'ung pretends to be the official report of the discussions on the Classics which were held under Imperial auspices in 79 A.D.,

reason.p: Could be useful for delivery. As is our usual practice, n is simply a label for display; n is not being used as a transcriptional space here, since the number/label of the div is transcribed in the divisions head.

practice.head: Half-titles, fly-titles, and divisional titles
practice.desc: Encode half-titles as div1 type="half-title" within front. Encode fly-titles as div1 type="fly-title" within front. Encode divisional titles as head type="divisional" within the divN that it precedes.

remarks.p: A common feature in many books is a heading (on a separate page, or at the top of the first page of the first chapter) containing the title of the work (or the title of a section of the work). There are three main types of such features:

list.item: A page preceding the title page and bearing the title of the work, perhaps with a series title or volume number, is a half-title page and should be marked as div1 type="half-title" within front.

A page similar to a half-title page but occurring between the front matter and the body is a fly-title and should be marked as div1 type="fly-title" as the last division within front (not as the first division of the body).

A page, or just an initial heading preceding other headings, similar to a half-title but occurring within the body of the work, to announce the beginning of a major section, is a divisional title. In contrast to half-title and fly-title pages within the front matter, a divisional title should not be marked with its own divN. Instead, the divisional title should be incorporated into the divN that it precedes, as a head element.

exemplum.eg:
The Original Journals of Captains Meriwether | Lewis and William Clark THE JOURNALS PROPER The ORIGINAL JOURNALS OF | LEWIS AND CLARK Chapter I FROM RIVER DUBOIS TO THE PLATTE Clark's Journal and Orders, January 30–July 22, 1804 | Entries and Orders by Lewis, February 20, March 3, May 15, 20, 26, and July 8, 12 [PRELIMINARY MEMORANDA] [Clark]

CAPTS. LEWIS & CLARK wintered at the enterance | of a Small river opposit the Mouth of Missouri |

The Original Journals of Captains Meriwether Lewis and William Clark THE JOURNALS PROPER The ORIGINAL JOURNALS OF LEWIS AND CLARK Chapter I FROM RIVER DUBOIS TO THE PLATTE Clark's Journal and Orders, January 30–July 22, 1804 Entries and Orders by Lewis, February 20, March 3, May 15, 20, 26, and July 8, 12 [PRELIMINARY MEMORANDA] [Clark]

CAPTS. LEWIS & CLARK wintered at the enterance of a Small river opposit the Mouth of Missouri

practice.head: Informal divisions
practice.desc: It is fairly common (especially in poems, but also in prose works) to see informal divisions, indicated by a string of asterisks or periods, or by a horizontal line. Normally, such informal dividers do not indicate the beginning of a new divN. Instead, they should be marked as ornament elements.

practice.head: Quoted material
practice.desc: In cases where a brief section of verse, a letter, or other material is quoted within surrounding prose text, the material should be marked as a block quotation using q, not as a distinct divN.

practice.head: Multiple headings
practice.desc: If a division (or other feature) has more than one heading, use multiple head elements (rather than a single head with line breaks), and include the type attribute with one of these values: main, sub, desc (descriptive), alt (alternative), or divisional (for divisional titles; see ).

exemplum.p: In this example, the main heading identifies the division as a chapter and gives its number, the sub-heading indicates the content of the chapter, and the descriptive heading indicates the manuscript materials represented in the chapter.
exemplum.eg:
The ORIGINAL JOURNALS OF | LEWIS AND CLARK Chapter I FROM RIVER DUBOIS TO THE PLATTE Clark's Journal and Orders, January 30–July 22, 1804 | Entries and Orders by Lewis, February 20, March 3, May 15, 20, 26, and July 8, 12 [PRELIMINARY MEMORANDA] [Clark]

CAPTS. LEWIS & CLARK wintered at the enterance | of a Small river opposit the Mouth of Missouri |

The ORIGINAL JOURNALS OF LEWIS AND CLARK Chapter I FROM RIVER DUBOIS TO THE PLATTE Clark's Journal and Orders, January 30–July 22, 1804 Entries and Orders by Lewis, February 20, March 3, May 15, 20, 26, and July 8, 12 [PRELIMINARY MEMORANDA] [Clark]

CAPTS. LEWIS & CLARK wintered at the enterance of a Small river opposit the Mouth of Missouri

remarks.p: The DTD enumerates the possible values for type on head, but it doesnt require type because its unnecessary if theres only one head. The QA program can only verify that, if multiple heads are present, they each have the type attribute. It cannot determine that multiple heads should have been used (rather than a single head with line breaks, since line breaks are often needed/legitimate within a heading), or that the appropriate type values have been used.

practice.head: Exactly one titlePage
practice.desc: Normally a text should have exactly one titlePage element.

remarks.p: Although a text with more or less than one titlePage is theoretically possible and technically allowed by the DTD, such an occurrence is extremely rare and should be regarded as an encoding error unless proven otherwise.

practice.head: Title types
practice.desc: When using titlePart to mark the parts of the title, include the type attribute, assigning one of these values: main, sub, desc (descriptive), alt (alternative), or volume (for volume information).

practice.head: Volume information on title page
practice.desc: Volume information on the title page should be encoded as titlePart type="volume".

remarks.p: This rule holds true even if the volume information is separated from the title by the byline or other elements (titlePart is allowed outside docTitle).

practice.head: Verso of title page
practice.desc: The content on the verso (reverse side) of the title page should be included within the titlePage element, typically inside docImprint.

remarks.p: This practice is machine-enforceable in the sense that the QA program checks for exactly two pb elements within titlePage.

practice.head: Openers and closers
practice.desc: When encoding letters, prefaces, and other such personal writings, use opener and/or closer as needed to encode the opening and closing sections of the division.

remarks.p: opener and closer typically contain one or more of these elements:

list.item: contains a date in any format; use the value attribute to provide the date in standardized format; see
contains a proper name; use type to indicate person or place.
salutation at the beginning (e.g. Dear Sir) or end (e.g. Yours sincerely) of a letter
signature at the end of a letter, preface, etc.

exemplum.eg:
TO MRS. H. LINCOLN.1 Weymouth, 5 October, 1761. MY DEAR FRIEND,

Does not my friend think me a stupid girl, when | she has kindly offered to correspond with me, that | I should be so senseless as not to accept the offer? |

I can say, in the length of this epistle, I've made | the golden rule mine. Pray, my friend, do not let it | be long before you write to your ever affectionate

A. S. P.S. My regards to your good man. I've no | acquaintance with him, but if you love him, I do, | and should be glad to see him.

Does not my friend think me a stupid girl, when she has kindly offered to correspond with me, that I should be so senseless as not to accept the offer?

I can say, in the length of this epistle, I've made the golden rule mine. Pray, my friend, do not let it be long before you write to your ever affectionate

practice.head: Postscripts
practice.desc: Postscripts in letters should be encoded using ps within closer.

practice.head: Postscripts
practice.desc: Postscripts in letters should be encoded using seg type="postscript" rend="block" within closer.

practice.head: Indented lines
practice.desc: If a line of verse is indented more than the surrounding lines, use l rend="indent". In cases of multiple levels of indentation, use indent for the first level, indent2 for the second level, etc. potentially through indent5.

practice.head: Line breaks in verse
practice.desc: When encoding verse it is important to distinguish between logical lines of verse and the physical presentation of those lines on the printed page. In cases where a line of verse is too long to fit on the printed page, and for that reason is continued on a second line, use l to mark the logical line of verse and | (vertical bar character) to mark the physical line break.

practice.head: Line breaks in verse
practice.desc: When encoding verse it is important to distinguish between logical lines of verse and the physical presentation of those lines on the printed page. In cases where a line of verse is too long to fit on the printed page, and for that reason is continued on a second line, use l to mark the logical line of verse and lb/ to mark the physical line break.

practice.head: Encoding dramatic works
practice.desc: Use the standard TEI elements for encoding plays and other dramatic texts.

list.item: act and scene divisions should be marked as divN elements
speeches should be marked as sp, with speakers marked as speaker
stage directions should be marked as stage
castlists should be marked as div1 type="castlist" within front

practice.head: Layout
practice.desc: Although the layout of a newspaper page is more complex than a book page, the usual elements are used: pb for page breaks, cb/ for column breaks, and cols/ for changes in columnar layout.

practice.head: Associating related sections
practice.desc: Because newspaper articles are often broken up and printed in two (or more) non-contiguous sections, it is necessary to link the first section of the article with the subsequent section(s). Use the id, next and prev attributes on divN elements to achieve this.

exemplum.eg:
<div1 type="article" id="a1.3" next="a14.2"> <!-- first part of newspaper article --> </div1>
<!-- multiple pages of content here -->
<div1 type="article" id="a14.2" prev="a1.3"> <!-- continuation of article --> </div1>

remarks.p: Because the datatype of next and prev is IDREF, the DTD enforces that these attributes point to an ID somewhere in the XML document. To verify that the ID is on a certain kind of div, or to verify that next points to an element whose prev attribute points back to it, a QA program would be necessary.

practice.head: Encyclopedia entries
practice.desc: Encyclopedia entries typically consist mainly of prose paragraphs and do not normally pose any special markup issues. Each encyclopedia entry is a divN element containing one or more headings followed by paragraphs.

practice.head: Simple entries
practice.desc: In the simplest case, a dictionary entry has minimal grammatical information and only one definition.

exemplum.p: After-night, n. The time after it becomes night.
exemplum.eg:
After-night,
n. The time after it becomes night.
<entry> <form><orth><hi rend="bold">After-night,</hi></orth></form> <gramGrp><pos><hi rend="italic">n.</hi></pos></gramGrp> <def>The time after it becomes night.</def> </entry>

practice.head: Alternate spellings and usage examples
practice.desc: Alternate spellings should be marked with orth type="alt". Usage examples should be marked with eg.

remarks.p: The eg element does not allow character data; instead, eg must contain q (for examples with no attributed source) or cit (for examples that include an attribution of the author or source text).

admon.p: Because DLPS normally uses q for block quotations, when using q in a dictionary entry please indicate q rend="inline", as shown in the following example.

exemplum.p:
Again, conj. Agen; agin: By the time that, untill: Ill have
it ready agin you come.
exemplum.eg:
Again,
conj.
Agen; agin:
By the time that, untill: "I'll have | it ready agin you come."

<entry rend="hang"> <form><orth><hi rend="bold">Again,</hi></orth></form> <gramGrp><pos><hi rend="italic">conj.</hi></pos></gramGrp> <form><orth type="alt"><hi rend="italic">Agen; agin:</hi></orth></form> <def>By the time that, untill:</def> <eg><q rend="inline">"I'll have <lb/> it ready <hi rend="italic">agin</hi> you come."</q></eg> </entry>

practice.head: Multiple homographs and multiple meanings
practice.desc: More complex dictionary entries may include more than one form of the same word that is, multiple homographs (words identical in spelling but different in meaning or pronunciation), each marked with hom. Entries may also include more than one meaning for the same word, in which case the information (definitions, examples, etc.) for each meaning should be grouped as a sense. If the senses are labeled with numbers or letters in the print source, include the label in the n attribute.

exemplum.p:
Against, prep. In resistance to; or defense from They
marched against the Spaniards. (2.) Opposite. Over
against a point called Sandy Point. Against, conj. Keep
em against I come.

Against,

practice.head: Super entries
practice.desc: In cases where words with identical spellings (homographs) receive separate entries in the dictionary (rather than being included within a single entry), each entry should be marked as an entry as usual, but then the group of entries should be wrapped in a superEntry element.

exemplum.eg:
Pitch,
n. The height of anything. "The roof was ten feet | pitch." "Tester bedstead 7½ feet pitch."
Pitch,
v. To pitch in, to begin; set to work with promptness | or energy. (2.) To pitch into, to attack; assault.
Pitch,
v. To sit down; to light. "I saw wild geese pitch | in the wheatfields."
Pitch,
v. To plant. "I have already pitched my crop."
Pitcher,
n. A vessel of various sizes with one handle and a | lip-spout for holding water or other liquids. A basin and | pitcher. Never called jug.

practice.head: Block quotations
practice.desc: Block quotations should be encoded using the q element.

remarks.p: By block quotation we simply mean a quotation set off from the surrounding text by one or more of these typographic changes:

list.item: set off by line breaks
indented
in a smaller typeface

remarks.p: q is always used for block quotations, irrespective of whether or not the narrator/author attributes the quotation to an external source; that is, the quote element should never be used.

practice.head: q and quotation marks
practice.desc: q should never be used to replace quotation marks. If the quotation is both set off typographically from the surrounding text and enclosed in quotation marks, use the q element and also include the quotation marks.

practice.head: Captions and associated text
practice.desc: When using the figure element to indicate graphical content (illustrations, photographs, maps, etc.), use the head element to record the caption of the figure (if any). Use the p element to record text (if any) that is associated with the figure but is not part of the caption.

remarks.p: If the graphic has a credit or byline, use the byline element within figure.

practice.head: rend attribute on figure
practice.desc: The rend attribute is required on figure.

remarks.p: rend indicates how the figure appears on the page in the physical source (not how it is intended to appear on screen in an electronic display).
The allowed values are:

list.item: figure occurs on same line as surrounding text content
figure is set off by line breaks, with no text to the left or right of the figure
figure occupies the entire page

reason.p: It seems good practice inherently to record relation of figure to text. Facilitates delivery.

practice.head: A figure at the start of a division: frontispiece
practice.desc: A frontispiece is a figure that occurs at or near the beginning of a structural division.

remarks.p: The frontispiece element is identical to the figure element except that, unlike a figure, a frontispiece can occur at the top of a divN element.

There are cases where an illustration is the first component in a chapter or other structural division. This occurs most often when the figure is a full-page illustration on the page immediately preceding the first page of content for that division, and the illustration is clearly related to the content that follows it, not the content that precedes it. In such cases, the illustration should be marked as a frontispiece at the beginning of the new divN, not as a figure at the end of the preceding divN.

practice.head: Printers ornaments
practice.desc: Printers ornaments do not qualify as figures. Instead, printers ornaments should be encoded with ornament type="ornament"/

practice.head: Horizontal lines
practice.desc: Horizontal lines should be encoded using the ornament element. For true horizontal lines, set type to line. For a string of asterisks, periods, etc. that functions as a horizontal line, set type to characters and include the characters as the content of the ornament element.

exemplum.eg:
<ornament type="line"/>
<ornament type="characters">* * * * * * * *</ornament>

remarks.p: The qa_lib_misc QA program verifies that if type=characters, the ornament element must contain text (must not be empty), and that if type=line (or type=ornament), the ornament element must be empty. But there is no machine-enforceable way to ensure that horizontal lines are marked properly, or marked at all.

practice.head: Label cells
practice.desc: For cells that contain a label or heading, rather than data, use cell role="label".

remarks.p: For cells containing data, there is no need to include the role attribute; data is the default value.

practice.head: Spanning rows or columns
practice.desc: If a cell occupies more than one row or column, use the rows or cols attribute, respectively, on the cell start-tag.

remarks.p: This usage is equivalent to the use of the rowspan and colspan attributes on td and th in HTML.

reason.p: Facilitates delivery: equates to rowspan and colspan in HTML.

practice.head: Tables vs. lists
practice.desc: In some cases, the choice between table and list may not be obvious, but typically any items of text that are intended to line up vertically should be encoded as a table. A table of contents, list of illustrations, etc. should almost always be marked up as a table.

practice.head: Nested lists
practice.desc: Lists can be nested (a list item can contain a list). A common use of nested lists is for indexes where each entry contains indented sub-entries.

practice.head: Anchored note references: ref
practice.desc: In cases where the note reference is indicated by a number or symbol, as is almost always true of footnotes and endnotes, use ref to encode the note reference.

remarks.p: By note reference we mean the anchor point for the annotation within the flow of the main text, typically indicated with a superscript number or symbol. By note body we mean the content of the annotation.

Enforced by the DTD insofar as the DTD disallows the use of target on note (VENDOR mode only), thereby disallowing the use of note target="..." to encode the note reference (at the point of initial/vendor encoding).

practice.head: Unanchored note references: ptr/
practice.desc: In cases where no number or other referencing symbol is present, as is common for marginal notes, use ptr/ to supply an anchor point for the annotation.

practice.head: target attribute required for note reference
practice.desc: Whether using ref or ptr/ to encode the note reference, the target attribute is required, and its value must match the value of the id attribute of the corresponding note.

remarks.p: This rule is machine-enforceable insofar as the DTD requires target on ref and ptr/, where target (datatype IDREFS) must refer to an ID within the XML document. The QA program further requires (unless place=inline) that each note must be pointed to by a ref or ptr/ element (not by any element). But no DTD or QA program can ensure that a ref or ptr/ points to the correct corresponding note, and in this regard this rule is unenforceable (except by painstaking human effort).

practice.head: Placement of note elements within the XML document
practice.desc: With the exception of endnotes, which are already located in a separate section in the print source and should not be moved, the note element should be placed at the point of the notes attachment in the main text that is, immediately after the corresponding ref or ptr/ element.

practice.head: Note symbols
practice.desc: When the note body includes the referencing symbol (a number, *, , etc.), record this symbol using the ns (note symbol) element as the first element within note.

practice.head: Note symbols
practice.desc: When the note body includes the referencing symbol (a number, *, , etc.), record this symbol using seg type="note-symbol" as the first element within note.

remarks.p: Because a note symbol is almost always printed for anchored notes (footnotes and endnotes), the QA program issues a warning if the first child element of note is not seg type="note-symbol", unless anchored=no.

reason.p: Isolation of the note symbol is expected to facilitate delivery, especially if the delivery system chooses to suppress the printed note symbol and instead use the n value for display.

practice.head: Note symbol on note vs. note symbol on ref
practice.desc: The content of noteseg type="note-symbol" should match the content of that notes corresponding ref.

remarks.p: The reason this rule applies to POSTKB only is that the vendor is not authorized to make corrections. If the note symbols on ref and note do not match due to a printing error, DLPS can correct it using corr; the vendor cannot.

practice.head: n attribute for notes
practice.desc: The n attribute is required on both the note reference (ref or ptr/) and the note body (note). Its value should be a label for display, which may or may not be equivalent to the note symbol transcribed from the print source (for note reference, content of ref; for note body, content of noteseg type="note-symbol").

remarks.p: The QA program requires n on note (except in teiHeader), and also on ref and ptr/.
Compliance with this practice is automated: The processing script notes_n programmatically adds the n attribute on note, ref, and ptr/ elements.

reason.p: Facilitates delivery. If n is always present and always carries a label for display, delivery of notes is greatly facilitated, without interfering at all with the transcriptional content.

practice.head: n on note reference vs. n on note body
practice.desc: The value of n on note must match the value of n on that notes corresponding ref or ptr/.

practice.head: id required on note
practice.desc: The id attribute is required on note.

practice.head: place required on note
practice.desc: The place attribute is required on note.

remarks.p: The DTD requires place and enumerates the allowed values, but of course no DTD can ensure appropriate use of the allowed values.

practice.head: id and place on note
practice.desc: The id and place attributes are required on note, except in teiHeader.

remarks.p: Because note is needed in teiHeader, the requirement of id and place cannot be DTD-enforced at the post-keyboarding stage (as it is for vendor markup). In the context of teiHeader, id is not necessary (no ref refers to the note) and place is not applicable (there is no physical placement, no print source for the note).

practice.head: Unanchored notes
practice.desc: If a note is unanchored (has no corresponding note reference that is, is pointed to by ptr/ rather than ref; typically marginal notes), include the anchored attribute with value no.

reason.p: Explicitness; could facilitate delivery

practice.head: Multiple references to a single note
practice.desc: It is possible for multiple ref or ptr/ elements to point to a single note element. In such cases, the note element should not be repeated. Instead, the note should be transcribed once and placed after the first ref or ptr/ that points to that note.

practice.head: Other features
practice.desc: Arguments, bibliographic citations, epigraphs, and trailers should be marked using the appropriate TEI elements.

exemplum.p: An epigraph containing a quotation, along with attribution of its source:
exemplum.eg: "I have sworn upon the altar of God | eternal hostility against every form of tyranny | over the mind of man." — Thomas Jefferson.

<epigraph> <cit> <q>"I have sworn upon the altar of God <lb/> eternal hostility against every form of tyranny <lb/> over the mind of man."</q> <bibl><author> — <hi rend="italic">Thomas Jefferson.</hi></author></bibl> </cit> </epigraph>
<trailer>FINIS.</trailer>

practice.head: Arguments
practice.desc: An argument is a block of content near the beginning of a divN containing a summary or overview of that section. It is often (though certainly not always) presented as a series of topics separated by long dashes. An argument should be marked as an argument, not as a second head or as the first p.

exemplum.eg:
CHAPTER VIII.

Absence of public and private Amusement—Churches | and Chapels—Influence of the Clergy—A Revival.

I never saw any people who appeared to live so | much without amusement as the Cincinnatians. |

CHAPTER VIII.

Absence of public and private Amusement—Churches and Chapels—Influence of the Clergy—A Revival.

I never saw any people who appeared to live so much without amusement as the Cincinnatians.

practice.head: Changes in typeface
practice.desc: With the exception of foreign phrases, changes in typeface should be marked with the appropriate physical element, not with a logical element such as emph, title, term, mentioned, etc.

remarks.p: When marking changes in typeface, the following elements should be used whenever applicable:
For all other typographic changes, use hi rend="...", using one of the following available values for the rend attribute:

list.item: assumed and not normally necessary
indicate rendering using the other attribute, as in: hi rend="other" other="..." (Of course, hi should be used in this way only as a last resort.)

remarks.eg: New York THE MACMILLAN COMPANY | LONDON: MACMILLAN & CO., Ltd. 1899 All rights reserved

remarks.p: As a whole this practice is enforced, or at least greatly encouraged, by the DTD by way of (a) availability of convenience elements i, b, etc.; (b) controlled vocabulary on rend, which disallows values like italic italics ital etc.; (c) rend is required on hi

practice.head: Changes in typeface
practice.desc: With the exception of foreign phrases, the vendor has been instructed to mark changes in typeface as physical changes, not with a logical element such as emph, title, term, mentioned, etc. At the post-keyboarding stage, this practice continues. For the sake of consistency, and as a matter of practical necessity, DLPS does not normally undertake the enhanced, logical markup of changes in typeface.

remarks.p: The most common values for the rend attribute on hi are:

list.item: super superscript
sub subscript

remarks.p: Less common but valid values are:

list.item: roman assumed and not normally necessary
other indicate rendering using the other attribute, as in: hi rend="other" other="..." (Of course, hi should be used in this way only as a last resort.)

remarks.p: The value gothic should be used for the gothic or black-letter style of typeface. In modern printed books, gothic type is typically used to highlight a name or brief passage.
remarks.eg: <docImprint> <pubPlace><hi rend="gothic">New York</hi></pubPlace> <publisher>THE MACMILLAN COMPANY <lb/> LONDON: MACMILLAN & CO., <hi rend="small-caps">Ltd.</hi></publisher> <docDate>1899</docDate> <hi rend="italic">All rights reserved</hi>

remarks.p: Enforced by the DTD in that rend is required on hi, and rend has an enumerated vocabulary. But as always, the appropriate use of hi and its available rend values is not machine-enforceable.

reason.p: While ideally changes in typeface would always be encoded with the appropriate logical element, in practice this is not feasible for vendor-produced markup. The encoders may not be native speakers of English and should not be expected to make the appropriate semantic distinctions or determine the authors rhetorical intention. Instead, such distinctions should be reserved for second-pass markup by a native speaker of English, perhaps even a subject-matter specialist. Note, however, that such second-pass markup is not a part of the DLPS workflow. Normally a text will receive such enhanced, logical markup only if someone outside DLPS (faculty member, Info Comm, Etext Center, etc.) happens to take an interest in the text and brings the resources (funding, staff, etc.) to undertake the additional markup.

practice.head: Small caps
practice.desc: Text that is printed in small caps should be transcribed using both upper-case and lower-case letters, not all upper-case letters.

exemplum.eg:
CONNECTICUT.

There was no press in this colony until 1709; and, I | believe, not more than four printing houses in it before | 1775.

New London.

The first printing done in Connecticut was in that town; |

CONNECTICUT.

There was no press in this colony until 1709; and, I believe, not more than four printing houses in it before 1775.

New London.

The first printing done in Connecticut was in that town;

reason.p: This is the simplest way to distinguish the fully capitalized letters from the small-caps letters. The alternative method of marking small caps would be to mark only the small-caps letters, leaving the fully capitalized letters unmarked, for example:
reason.eg: H<hi rend="small-caps">ERE</hi>, A<hi rend="small-caps">BANDON</hi> A<hi rend="small-caps">LL</hi> H<hi rend="small-caps">OPE</hi>
reason.p: rather than simply
The former is ugly, tag-heavy, and unnecessary.

practice.head: Representing alignment and indentation
practice.desc: When indicating alignment or indentation, use the rend attribute, either on structural elements (p, l, cell, item, etc.) or on hi, as appropriate to the situation.

remarks.p: For indicating alignment, the available rend values are:

list.item: assumed and not normally necessary

remarks.p: For indicating indentation, the available rend values are:

list.label: indent2, indent3, indent4, indent5
list.item: for cases where more than one level of indentation needs to be recorded (Use these values sparingly, and only when indent has already been used. Normally these values are only needed when encoding lines of verse.)
for hanging indentation that is, when the first line of content is further left than subsequent lines; common in lists, such as indexes

remarks.p: Enforced by the DTD in the sense that rend has an enumerated vocabulary, but as always, the appropriate use of the available rend values is not machine-enforceable.

reason.p:
Originally the DTD Practices Group recommendations limited global rend to block, inline, or none, with the intention of encouraging the nesting of typographic markup within structural markup (for example,

...

rather than

...

), partly for inherent logical/semantic reasons and partly to facilitate writing stylesheets for delivery. In practice this came to seem counterintuitive for marking alignment and indentation, especially for marking lines of verse, where indentation markup is common. We decided to consider alignment and indentation as properties of the elements themselves, not as a form of highlighting (for example, ... is preferable to ..., since the line itself is indented; the text within the line is not being highlighted). That is, we decided to distinguish between display (block, inline, or none), alignment (center, left, or right), and indentation (indent, indent2 etc., or hang) on the one hand, and typographic changes on the other.

practice.head: Default alignment
practice.desc: Some elements have a presumed or default alignment and do not normally require explicit alignment markup.

list.item: center
center
center
list.label: elements within titlePage
list.item: center
center
center
right
list.label: salute within opener
list.item: left
list.label: salute within closer
list.item: right, with some indentation toward the left
right
list.label: all other elements
list.item: left

remarks.p: These elements should contain alignment markup only when the layout of the element on the printed page differs from the defaults listed above.
This practice is unenforceable. Its usefulness (apart from saving keystrokes) depends entirely on the delivery system being aware of these default alignments.

practice.head: Use of foreign
practice.desc: Words or phrases that are both (a) typographically distinct (usually in italics), and (b) not in the main language of the text, should be marked with the foreign element.

reason.p: The reasons for requiring that foreign phrases must be typographically distinct to warrant foreign are that (a) the keyboarding vendor can know unambiguously when to use foreign, and (b) if the phrase is not italicized or otherwise distinct, it is presumably so common as to have lost its foreign-ness, at least in the authors (or copy editors, or typesetters) estimation.

practice.head: lang attribute on foreign
practice.desc: Whenever possible, include the lang attribute on foreign, using one of the standard ISO 639-2 three-character language codes. In cases where the language is not obvious, mark the phrase with foreign but omit lang.

remarks.p: Commonly used ISO 639-2 codes include:

list.item: French
German
Greek, ancient (to 1453)
Greek, modern (1453- )
Hebrew
Italian
Latin
Russian
Spanish

remarks.p: While a QA program could issue a warning if a foreign element has no lang attribute, we have not deemed it a good use of the QA techs time to manually double-check/second-guess the vendors omission of the lang attribute.

practice.head: Declaring languages
practice.desc: Each language identified by a lang attribute (on foreign, or on any other element) must be declared in a language element within the teiHeader.

exemplum.eg: <profileDesc> <langUsage> <language id="eng" usage="main">English</language> <language id="fre">French</language> </langUsage> </profileDesc>
exemplum.p: In the body of the text:
exemplum.eg: This the reader is willing to | accept as a possible occurrence; but when she | goes on to say that having completed his dem- | onstration, this person triumphantly replaced | his pencil-case, and with his feet upon the chimney- | piece whistled Yankee Doodle, c'est un peu | trop fort, and we are probably justified in set- | ting it down as a bit of literary colour.

This the reader is willing to accept as a possible occurrence; but when she goes on to say that having completed his dem- onstration, this person triumphantly replaced his pencil-case, and with his feet upon the chimney- piece whistled Yankee Doodle, c'est un peu trop fort, and we are probably justified in set- ting it down as a bit of literary colour.

remarks.p: Although the lang attribute is declared as type IDREF, a validating parser can only verify that the value of lang corresponds to an ID somewhere in the XML document. The QA program checks whether lang actually corresponds to a language id="..." within teiHeader/profileDesc/langUsage.

practice.head: Retaining typographic distinction
practice.desc: Using the foreign element does not eliminate the need to encode the change in typeface using i, b, etc.

remarks.p: Since foreign phrases are usually italicized, typical markup for a foreign phrase will be: ...

practice.head: Retaining typographic distinction
practice.desc: Using the foreign element does not eliminate the need to encode the change in typeface using hi.

remarks.p: Since foreign phrases are usually italicized, typical markup for a foreign phrase will be: <foreign lang="..."><hi rend="italic">...</hi></foreign>

reason.p: Explicitness. This approach is preferable to assuming that foreign content is italicized, on the same principle as avoiding the use of default values for attributes: if theres a default value, encoders tend to ignore the attribute altogether and thus forget to use it when its actually applicable, resulting in erroneous (or missing) markup.

practice.head: Not roman but not Asian
practice.desc: Languages such as Greek, Hebrew, and Russian fall into a special category. They require non-roman characters, but they are alphabetic, not ideographic. If the language is within the vendors capabilities, the foreign content should be included in the electronic transcription. If the language is not within the vendors capabilities, omit the characters from the transcription and use the gap/ element to mark the location of the omitted characters.

remarks.p: When transcribing these kinds of languages, use the appropriate character entities, when available (namely Greek), or XML character references with Unicode hexadecimal values:

list.label: Greek
list.item: Use the iso-grk1.ent character entities, supplemented as needed by the accented characters in iso-grk2.ent
list.label: Hebrew
list.item: Use the Hebrew block of Unicode (0590 - 05FF)
list.label: Russian
list.item: Use the Cyrillic block of Unicode (0400 - 04FF)

practice.head: Standard keyboard punctuation
practice.desc: Most common punctuation characters can and should be represented using their normal keyboard characters.

practice.head: Use of character entities
practice.desc: Marks of punctuation other than those listed above must be represented using their standard character entities.

list.label: ampersand
list.item: & (as required by XML)
list.label: vertical bar
list.item: | (since the vendor is required to use the vertical bar character ( | ) to represent line breaks; see )
list.label: em dash
list.item: — (long dash)
list.label: en dash
list.item: – (medium-length dash, often used to indicate a range, for example: 1783–1804)

remarks.p: Other marks of punctuation are available in the iso-num.ent, iso-pub.ent, and iso-tech.ent character entity sets. See .

practice.head: Ellipses
practice.desc: An ellipse a series of dots or asterisks indicating deliberately omitted text should be indicated by a series of keyboard-character periods or asterisks. Simply use the same number of periods or asterisks used in the print source.

practice.head: Long spaces
practice.desc: If the print source contains an exceptionally long space that needs to be preserved (for example, to indicate a word deliberately omitted by the author), use a series of   (em space) entities.

practice.head: Spacing between sentences
practice.desc: Use one space character between sentences, not two, regardless of the apparent spacing in the print source.

reason.p: Saves keystrokes. Multiple spaces will be collapsed to a single space by web browsers at the point of delivery anyway.

practiceGroup.head: Dates
practiceGroup.practice:
Date values On date, the value attribute is required. On dateRange, the to and from attributes are required.
&reason_date;

Standardized date formats The values of attributes where the datatype is %ISO-date; namely value on date, and to and from on dateRange must be in one of the machine-readable formats listed below.
Formats:
YYYY-MM-DD
YYYY-MM
YYYY
-MM-DD
--DD
BC/BCE dates are represented in the same way, but prefixed with a "B". <date value="B233" type="death">d. 233 B.C.</date>
<date value="1901-08-04">4 Aug., 1901</date> <date value="1870-03">March 1870</date> <date value="2003">2003</date> <date value="-01-20">Jan. 20th</date>
&reason_date;

practice.head: Mathematical formulas
practice.desc: Short mathematical or scientific formulas should be represented textually using the formula element. For long or complex formulas, omit the textual representation and instead represent the formula as a graphic using the figure element.

remarks.p: Within formula, mark superscript or subscript text in the usual way. Include the required notation attribute with the value informal.
When using figure to represent a long formula, if the formula is printed within the flow of the surrounding text, use rend=inline. If the formula is set off by line breaks, use rend=block.

exemplum.eg: knew not enough mathematics even to figure a formula beyond | the schoolboy <formula notation="informal">s=gt<sup>2</sup> / 2</formula>. If Kepler and Newton could take liberties | with the sun and moon, an obscure person in a remote wilderness | like La Fayette Square could take liberties with Congress, and | venture to multiply half its attraction into the square of its time. |

knew not enough mathematics even to figure a formula beyond <lb/> the schoolboy <formula notation="informal">s=gt<hi rend="super">2</hi> / 2</formula>. If Kepler and Newton could take liberties <lb/> with the sun and moon, an obscure person in a remote wilderness <lb/> like La Fayette Square could take liberties with Congress, and <lb/> venture to multiply half its attraction into the square of its time. <lb/>
exemplum.p: Although the formula shown here is short and simple enough to be represented using formula, if it were a long or complex formula requiring figure, the markup would be as follows:
exemplum.eg: knew not enough mathematics even to figure a formula beyond | the schoolboy <figure rend="inline"/>. If Kepler and Newton could take liberties | with the sun and moon, an obscure person in a remote wilderness | like La Fayette Square could take liberties with Congress, and | venture to multiply half its attraction into the square of its time. |

knew not enough mathematics even to figure a formula beyond <lb/> the schoolboy <figure rend="inline"/>. If Kepler and Newton could take liberties <lb/> with the sun and moon, an obscure person in a remote wilderness <lb/> like La Fayette Square could take liberties with Congress, and <lb/> venture to multiply half its attraction into the square of its time. <lb/>

reason.p: The goal here is simply to provide a mechanism for informal textual representation of the occasional mathematical formula in prose humanities texts. The textual representation is human-readable, the flow of the narrative is not interrupted, and there is no need to refer the reader to the page image (which would otherwise be necessary, because DLPS does not provide cropped, bitonal figure images for inline display).

practice.head: Marks beginning of page
practice.desc: The pb/ element marks the point at which a page begins, and so the pb/ element should always be placed at the top or beginning of the markup for that page, regardless of the position of the printed page number in the print source.

practice.head: Page numbers
practice.desc: If the page contains a printed page number, record it in the n attribute; if not, do not include the n attribute.

practice.head: Page number corrections
practice.desc: In cases where it is necessary to correct a page number (or add any other markup to a page number), insert an fw (form work) element within the pb element, and use corr as usual to make the correction. Put the correct number in the n attribute.

reason.p: We do not consider the n attribute on pb to be a transcriptional space; n is actually just a label for display. The n attribute is the most convenient and traditional place to record the page number, but in cases where tagging is needed around a page number, it is not possible in XML to add that tagging within an attribute value. For these reasons, we have opted to allow fw within pb. This approach is comparable to the distinction between printed note reference symbols and the n attribute on note. See .

practice.head: Always within a div
practice.desc: Page breaks must be placed within a divN element, never between divisions. Therefore, when a division starts on a new page, the pb is the first element in the division, immediately following the opening divN tag (preceding even the division head, if there is one).

exemplum.eg: </div2> <div2 type="chapter" n="II"> <pb/> <head>II—APPELLATIONS.</head>

remarks.p: The DTD disallows pb outside a div, but there is no way for the DTD to control exact placement of those pb elements within the div.

exceptions.p: The exception to this rule is newspapers, where the use of pb/ is reversed: pb/ is required to occur outside of any divN (pb/ is allowed only within body). This practice simply fits better with the nature of printed newspapers, where each page contains large amounts of text divided into numerous different divs, and where a div almost never continues to the next page uninterrupted.

practice.head: Blank pages
practice.desc: There must be one pb element for every page in the set of page images for the work. This is true even for pages that have no textual or graphical content on them. If a blank page occurs between divs, place the blank pages pb element as the last page of the preceding div, not as the first page of the new div.

exemplum.eg: BIBLIOGRAPHY

practice.head: Running page headers
practice.desc: Normally running page headers should be excluded from the electronic text, but in some cases (namely, when the running headers contain unique content not already available elsewhere in the transcription, such as a summary of that pages content) DLPS will specifically require that the running headers be preserved. To encode the running headers, use fw type="header" within pb.

exemplum.eg: <pb n="99"><fw type="header">APPEAL TO CHURCHES OF MASSACHUSETTS</fw></pb>

practice.head: Use of cb/
practice.desc: If the print source has a single-column layout, it is not necessary to mark the column at all. For materials with multiple columns, use cb/ to mark the beginning of each column on each page.

practice.head: Marks beginning of column
practice.desc: Like pb/ (page break), which always marks the beginning of the page, cb/ should always mark the top or beginning of the column of text.

practice.head: n attribute
practice.desc: Use the n attribute on cb/to record the number of the column on the page. For example, if each page contains two columns, the first (left) column on each page is <cb n="1"/>, and the second (right) column is <cb n="2"/>.

practice.head: Mixed column layouts
practice.desc: In cases where the number of columns changes mid-page, use the cols/ element to indicate the point at which the number of columns changes. Use the n attribute to indicate the number of columns in the section that follows the cols/ tag.

remarks.p: For example, if the page layout shifts from single-column to double-column in the midst of the page, use <cols n="2"/> to indicate the point at which double-column layout begins (and then use <cb n="1"/> and <cb n="2"/> to mark the columns, as usual). At the point where the layout shifts back to single-column text, use <cols n="1"/> (after which no cb/ elements are necessary, since the layout is single-column).

admon.p: A division head followed by a multi-column layout does not indicate a mixed-column layout and does not require cols n="..."/.

practice.head: Line breaks
practice.desc: Line breaks in running prose should be preserved in the electronic transcription by marking the end of each printed line with the | (vertical bar) character (standing in for the lb/ element).

admon.p: If the vertical bar character appears in the content of the text itself, use the | character entity to represent it.

practice.head: Line breaks
practice.desc: Line breaks in running prose should be preserved in the electronic transcription by marking the end of each printed line with lb/.

practice.head: Use of gap/
practice.desc: Use gap/ to mark any section (character, word, passage, page, etc.) that is being omitted from the transcription.

remarks.p: There are two reasons for such omissions: the section is missing (as happens with torn or missing pages), or it has been excluded deliberately for editorial reasons. In particular, a block of non-Western characters in a language outside the vendors capabilities should be marked as a gap/. Use one gap/ element for each unbroken section of content that is being excluded from the electronic transcription.

exemplum.xref: Example of use of gap/ for non-Western characters
Example of use of gap/ for non-Western characters

practice.head: desc and reason attributes on gap/
practice.desc: The desc (description) and reason attributes are required on gap/.

remarks.p: The value of desc should be a brief description of the content being omitted from the transcription. The reason attribute accepts these values:

list.item: the section is omitted deliberately for editorial reasons (for example, non-Western characters)
the section is omitted because of damage to the physical page (for example, a torn page)
the section is missing entirely (for example, a missing page)
indicate the reason in the other attribute, as in: <gap desc="..." reason="other" other="..."/>

exemplum.eg: <gap desc="Chinese characters" reason="editorial"/>
<gap desc="page 43, line 17 to end of page" reason="damage"/>

reason.p: Explicitness

practice.head: Use of unclear
practice.desc: Use unclear to mark passages that cannot be transcribed with certainty, as happens when a letter/word/phrase is physically present on the page but is unreadable (due to a printing error, physical damage to the page such as readers marks, or a bad scan).

remarks.p: When marking an illegible letter/word/phrase as unclear, transcribe the readable characters, omit the unreadable characters, and mark the entire word or phrase with <unclear>...</unclear>.
remarks.eg:
lost, wounded or captured in a fruitless and | <unclear>opeless</unclear> assault. | <-- ok
lost, wounded or captured in a fruitless and | <unclear/>opeless assault. | <-- wrong
remarks.p: If a word or phrase is so illegible that none of its characters can be read with certainty, use an empty unclear/ element to mark the point at which the word or phrase occurs.
remarks.eg: instead of his sargeant; and therefore no regiment | <unclear/> to be seen in which there are not soldiers in |

reason.p: Although ultimately we do not want partial words in the transcription, experience has shown that it is preferable for the vendor to do the best it can (transcribe all legible characters) and let us handle the unclears on our end as part of post-keyboarding processing.

practice.head: Use of unclear
practice.desc: Use unclear to mark passages that cannot be transcribed with certainty, as happens when a letter/word/phrase is physically present on the page but is unreadable (due to a printing error, physical damage to the page such as readers marks, or a bad scan).

remarks.p: When working with words or phrases marked by the vendor as unclear, follow these guidelines:

list.item: If a word marked as unclear by the vendor is actually legible (as can happen when a bad page image is rescanned and replaced only after the page images have shipped to the vendor), simply supply the characters necessary to complete the word and remove the unclear start-tag and /unclear end-tag.
If the word is unclear but a reasonable supposition can be made as to the intended word, supply the characters necessary to complete the word, but leave the unclear and /unclear markup in place.
If the word is so illegible that no reasonable supposition can be made, remove the entire illegible word/phrase and replace it with an empty unclear/ element.

practice.head: Arbitrary sections
practice.desc: When none of the standard TEI elements is appropriate for a particular textual feature, use ab if the feature is a block element or seg if the feature is within a containing block element.

remarks.p: In texts with complex structure or layout, the encoder is likely to encounter block-level sections or phrase-level passages that are difficult to fit into any of the standard TEI elements. In such cases, it may be best to take advantage of TEIs elements for arbitrary sections:

list.item: (anonymous block) occurs at the block level (at same level as p, table, list, etc.)
(segment) occurs at the phrase level (within p, cell, item, etc.)

remarks.p: Both of these elements accept the type attribute with any value (no predefined vocabulary).
Although these elements should be used sparingly, they are very useful when genuinely needed.

admon.p: It is better to use ab or seg, when appropriate, than to inject inappropriate markup such as divN elements that do not truly reflect the major structural divisions of the work, or p elements that are not really paragraphs for the sake of making it parse.

remarks.p: If a work contains a particularly problematic feature for which the preferred encoding is not clear, ask DLPS for further guidance.

practice.head: Character-entity sets
practice.desc: Character-entity sets are not declared in the external DTD. Instead, you will need to declare and invoke any entity sets required by a given document in the documents internal subset.

remarks.p: Although the character-entity files can be invoked using disk paths, we prefer the use of URLs, so that the document points to the latest version of the DTD and character-entity files.
remarks.eg:
<!DOCTYPE TEI.2 SYSTEM "http://text.lib.virginia.edu/dtd/tei/tei-p4/tei2.dtd" [
<!ENTITY % TEI.extensions.ent SYSTEM "http://text.lib.virginia.edu/dtd/tei/uva-dl-tei/uva-dl-tei.ent">
<!ENTITY % TEI.extensions.dtd SYSTEM "http://text.lib.virginia.edu/dtd/tei/uva-dl-tei/uva-dl-tei.dtd">

<!ENTITY % ISOlat1 SYSTEM "http://text.lib.virginia.edu/charent/iso-lat1.ent"> %ISOlat1;
<!ENTITY % ISOlat2 SYSTEM "http://text.lib.virginia.edu/charent/iso-lat2.ent"> %ISOlat2;
<!ENTITY % ISOnum  SYSTEM "http://text.lib.virginia.edu/charent/iso-num.ent">  %ISOnum;
<!ENTITY % ISOpub  SYSTEM "http://text.lib.virginia.edu/charent/iso-pub.ent">  %ISOpub;
<!ENTITY % ISOtech SYSTEM "http://text.lib.virginia.edu/charent/iso-tech.ent"> %ISOtech;
]>
remarks.p: The usual ISO 8879 (SGML) entity sets are included with the DLPS DTD files. Please do not use your own local versions of the ISO 8879 entity sets, as our versions include corrections, as well as a supplementary set containing characters not available in the standard sets (uva-supp.ent).

practice.head: Characters not in a standard entity set
practice.desc: Use the named (mnemonic) entities from the DLPS-supplied entity sets whenever possible, but if a particular character is not in one of the DLPS-supplied entity sets, declare a new character entity that resolves either to the appropriate Unicode character, or to a combination of a standard character and a Unicode combining diacritic.

remarks.p: If a character is not available in any of the DLPS-supplied entity sets (dont forget to check uva-supp.ent as well as the ISO 8879 sets), it may nevertheless be available as a Unicode character. In such cases, identify the correct Unicode character and declare it as an entity with an appropriate human-readable name.

In some cases, a particular character is not available in Unicode. It is usually possible, however, to create the needed character by combining a standard character with one of the Unicode combining diacritics (block 0300036F of Unicode).

practice.head: Adding to the files revision history
practice.desc: Before undertaking any significant markup correction or enhancement, add a change entry to the files revisionDesc (the last major element within teiHeader).

remarks.p: In the name element, include your first and last name (not just initials). Include the id attribute, using your UVa computing ID (which can then be used for the resp attribute on corr when making corrections; see ).

exemplum.eg:
March 8, 2005 Greg Murray (Digital Library Production Services, University of Virginia Library) corrector

Converted markup to validate against the DLPS DTD (uva-dl-tei) in its post-keyboarding mode. Overhauled div structures. Corrected note-related problems when encountered. Corrected minor printing errors.

practice.head: Use of corr
practice.desc: If the print source contains a blatant error, the error can and should be corrected in the electronic text. When making corrections, always use the corr element to mark the content that has been changed.

practice.head: sic attribute on corr
practice.desc: Whenever possible, include the sic attribute on corr; its value should be the original, uncorrected word/phrase from the print source.

remarks.p: Normally the only time sic should be missing is when correcting an error of omission, in which case there is nothing to record in the sic attribute.

practice.head: resp attribute on corr
practice.desc: When making corrections, include the resp (responsibility) attribute on corr. Its value should correspond to the id attribute of a name element within a respStmt in the teiHeader.

remarks.p: The typical scenario is to add an entry to the revision history for the file in teiHeader/revisionDesc (see ), then use resp to record responsibility for corrections.
remarks.eg: We have no <corr sic="trustworty" resp="gpm2a">trustworthy</corr> statistics <lb/>

remarks.p: The DTD does not require resp on corr, because in cases of conversion/migration of existing markup where the corrector is unknown, it is not always possible to supply a useful value for resp. Instead, the QA program issues a warning if resp is missing. The program also verifies that the resp value corresponds to the id attribute of an element within teiHeader. (This test goes beyond the DTD, which specifies that resp is an IDREF and so must point to an ID somewhere within the XML document. Actually, this test is performed for any and all elements that have a resp attribute, not just corr.)
